subject: RE: [junit] Re: JUnit automatically
msgSnippet: ...  ... How does Agitator cope with bad class design (re dependencies)?  When unit testing or TDDing *I* know/understand(?) the code I am working
messageBody:
albsavoia wrote:

> >How does a computer know what kinds of tests I need to write?
> >How does a computer know what the expected results are?
>
> Good questions J.B.
>

<snip />
> As you might guess, Agitator cannot know the expected results - only
> the developer can know that. What Agitator can do for you is
> generate test data that gets you code coverage and then shows you
> what it observed in the form of class and method invariants. These
> observations are in the form of Java boolean valued assertions. For
> example:

How does Agitator cope with "bad" class design (re dependencies)? When unit
testing or TDDing *I* know/understand(?) the code I am working with and
therefor can create the environment for my unit test to work in. For
example: I know that X requires access to singleton Y I do not have time to
rework Y out of the code but can use J.B.'s toolbox approach to mitigate
this. How does/can Agitator deal with this type of thing?
